qas.question: When was the new constitution for CAR approved?
When did a mutiny form against Patasse?
The mutinies caused what effects on the country?
Where did the peace corps evacuate to?
What agreement gave the authority for deployment of military intervention?
What did Yakoma accuse the Kolingba government of doing?
What group evacuated its volunteers to Cameroon in January 1997?
As of today what group has not returned to Yakoma?

plausible_answers.text: for the deployment of an inter-African military mission, to Central African Republic

qas.question: What did three mutinies signed in January 1997 provide for?
What was the Yakoma later replaced with?

context: Patassé purged many of the Kolingba elements from the government and Kolingba supporters accused Patassé's government of <b5_0>conducting a "witch hunt"<b5_0/> against the Yakoma. A new constitution was approved on <a0_0>28 December 1994<a0_0/> but had little impact on the country's politics. <a1_0>In 1996–1997<a1_0/>, reflecting steadily decreasing public confidence in the government's erratic behaviour, three mutinies against Patassé's administration were accompanied by <a2_0>widespread destruction of property<a2_0/> and heightened ethnic tension. During this time (1996) <b6_0>the Peace Corps<b6_0/> evacuated all its volunteers to neighboring <a3_0>Cameroon<a3_0/>. To date, <b7_0>the Peace Corps<b7_0/> has not returned to the Central African Republic. <a4_0>The Bangui Agreements<a4_0/>, signed in January 1997, provided <b8_0>for the deployment of an inter-African military mission, to Central African Republic<b8_0/> and re-entry of ex-mutineers into the government on 7 April 1997. The inter-African military mission was later replaced by <b9_0>a U.N. peacekeeping force<b9_0/> (MINURCA).
